channel.title: NYT > Badminton
channel.description: News about Badminton, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Video Replay Adopted
item.description: Badminton will introduce instant video review in June.
item.author: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Advances in Water Polo
item.description: The United States beat Italy, 9-6, moving on to the women’s water polo semifinals; the U.S. women’s volleyball team defeated Turkey; the Canadian women’s soccer coach criticized the U.S. team; badminton officials will examine the Olympic format.
item.author: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Roundup: Another Doubles Gold
item.description: LONDON - It's not easy being a professional athlete with an auto-immune disease, but the American tennis star Venus Williams is getting by with a little help from her sister Serena. On Sunday the Williams sisters returned to the All England Club, where last month they won their fifth Wimbledon doubles title, and secured their third Olympic women's doubles title with a 6-4, 6-4 victory against Andrea Hlavackova and Lucie Hradecka of the Czech Republic. The sisters' other Olympic doubles titl...
item.author: By KAREN CROUSE

item.title: In Battle Between Longtime Rivals, More Than One Gold Is in Offing
item.description: With a $600,000 bounty on the line, Lee Chong Wei of Malaysia took an early lead against Lin Dan of China in the badminton men’s final, but in the end he fell to his archrival.
item.author: By DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Consolation Prize for a Queens Club
item.description: There were bagels. There was badminton. And, in the end, there was bitter disappointment. At the CP Badminton Club in College Point, Queens, where groups of Malaysians often gather to play the game, about 25 enthusiasts gathered over breakfast early Sunday morning to watch the Olympic men's singles final between Lee Chong Wei of Malaysia and Lin Dan of China, the world's two best players and archrivals.
item.author: By CHRIS PALMER

item.title: U.S. Advances in Water Polo
item.description: The United States beat Italy, 9-6, moving on to the women’s water polo semifinals; the U.S. women’s volleyball team defeated Turkey; the Canadian women’s soccer coach criticized the U.S. team; badminton officials will examine the Olympic format.
item.author: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lin Dan Beats Lee Chong Wei in Men’s Olympic Badminton Final
item.description: With a $600,000 bounty on the line, Lee Chong Wei of Malaysia took an early lead against Lin Dan of China in the badminton men’s final, but in the end he fell to his archrival.
item.author: By DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Shame and Indignation in China as Its Olympians Come Under Fire
item.description: After a pair of badminton players were disqualified and a 16-year-old’s record swim victory was questioned, Chinese media pointed the blame in several directions.
item.author: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: The Goal Is Winning Gold, Not Winning Every Match
item.description: The four badminton teams that were disqualified Wednesday simply looked at the information presented to them and went in the direction that seemed to have the best chance of leading them to their goal.
item.author: By SAM BORDEN

item.title: After a Dispute, a Retirement
item.description: Yu Yang of China was one of eight athletes disqualified for deliberately trying to lose preliminary-round matches.
item.author: By KEN BELSON
